@firasalmanna not an official solution yet. One option is compiling the python to a native binary which you can do with `bbfreeze` or maybe `grumpy` (https://github.com/google/grumpy)`. Which packages are you looking at?

@rabbah 
I am trying to upload a project I am working on, requirements file attached. the requirements can be reduced as I am dividing my app into microservices, so each will have a subset of these requirements.
So after compiling my app into binary, how am I going to upload it? I don't think I saw this option in the docs.

[requirements.txt](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/files/730930/requirements.txt)

You can try the approach outlined here (once you have a binary you can create an action from it).

@csantanapr - assign to me please

Documenting plan:

1. Response is sized by the invoker.
	1. If it exceeds the system limit, the invoker will reject it.
	2. If it is within the limits, it will be processed as usual.
2. When the invoker rejects an action response, it will do the following:
	1. Construct an error response object with a message explaining the failure
	2. In addition, it will provide as a debugging aid a partial result that contains as many of the top level fields from the dictionary response into the error object.
3. The error response for large responses shall include:
	1. "Action result of X MB exceeds system limit of Y MB".
	1. The number of top level fields contained in the response and how many are actually included in the partial response.

As part of doing this work, I will also apply the same technique to reject large incoming payloads which currently get rejected a bit later in the pipeline than they should.
On 3.ii, also include the sizes of the fields so a user knows that the rejection was due to some particular field being too bug.
pushed in b5be59f..09471ee
@rabbah - Can you provide a sample output containing the tid.
See the tests: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1771/files#diff-d10642f754886a5c0a2ed7b403480fe7R219.
Also related to #1684.

What about in addition passing the tid in a header and also passing the tid on success ?

This way the http client doesn't matter success or error gets back a tid for meta invocation and potentially any type of invocation i.e. Regular invocation thru apigateway then there is potential to correlated logs from OpenWhisk and apigateway Server

Attaching the `tid` on a failed activation is consistent with the current error model: the response is an error, here's a ticket number should you want/need to investigate. The API defines the contract for error responses and so we can define that it shall contains an `error` field and a `code`.

When you're doing a blocking invoke, the response of the API is just the result of the action, on success. So where would you put the `tid`? In a custom header? Further, the `tid` is really to investigate system issues. Why should the system surface its own code when running user actions?

The meta actions are not special. They should not be treated as such. The action can log its activation ID and return a meaningful response to the user/caller (which could be its own activation id for example).
@csantanapr - PG1 1109 success.  Ready for review/merge
this is ready to merge as far as I'm concerned @markusthoemmes the ball is in your court
@csantanapr @lornajane Please review.
@ioana-blue if this is pg approved, please add corresponding label.
@starpit can you paste the error so it's easier to find the culprit in the code? thanks!
@rabbah can't add label, I'm just a contributor :)

@ioana-blue look in the resolve component names. The issue is that the strings "a/b" and "/a/b" are both deserialized into valid `FullyQualifiedEntityNames` that are ambiguous. I can see two solutions:
1. reject referenced entities that don't start with `/`
2. allow for some magic and if prefix the namespace if `/` is missing

We have in the past rejected 2 and think we should continue to.
I can't do any assignments on the right hand side of this window... to be more precise
A more radical approach: start requiring `default` for the default package when one is not present. No more ambiguity and we reject `default` as a package name.
@ioana-blue the error was of the "access denied" sort. i.e. completely unrelated to sequences.
PG3 210 approved.
all done. anything else?

Yeah I was talking returning via custom header. 

I think my comment is outside the scope of this this PR.

My comment was more the use case  it meta API but a call hitting the apigateway the. Doing an invoke, since to the outside world apigateway and core look one single system, was trying to see if there is a way to surface analytics on tracing the API call on going thru apigateway and the. Going thru different components of core.  But maybe a use case that doesn't hold water.  

Yes I agree that meta API is not special and having one way on tracking is proper approach for example apigw mgmt tasks/calls.

I had to modify the deploy playbook for mac as follows:

```
diff --git a/ansible/roles/invoker/tasks/deploy.yml b/ansible/roles/invoker/tasks/deploy.yml
index 9bd10e4..63d585d 100644
--- a/ansible/roles/invoker/tasks/deploy.yml
+++ b/ansible/roles/invoker/tasks/deploy.yml
@@ -30,15 +30,11 @@
     linuxOptions: "--pid=host --privileged -v /sys/fs/cgroup:/sys/fs/cgroup -v /run/runc:/run/runc -v /usr/bin/docker-runc:/usr/bin/docker-runc -v /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libapparmor.so.1:/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libapparmor.so.1"
   when: whisk_version_name != "mac"
 
-- set_fact:
-    linuxOptions: ""
-  when: not linuxOptions
-
 - name: start invoker using docker cli
   shell: >
         docker run -d
         --userns=host
-        {{ linuxOptions }}
+        {{ linuxOptions | default('') }}
         --name invoker{{play_hosts.index(inventory_hostname)}}
         --hostname invoker{{play_hosts.index(inventory_hostname)}}
         --restart {{ docker.restart.policy }}
```

There is a trade off involving invoker performance vs user debugging info. 

I would for starter implement 3.2 behind a configuration flag turned off by default that can be turn on in ansible then downstream/operator can choose if they want their invokers to suffer by always trying  parse/process the very large response into a json object into memory and the n inspecting the object to pick up fields to slim it down to fit the limit of 1mb 

 Iterating  over each field and check and try to come up with all the fields that summing them together will be close to 1mb and marking the fields that don't fit the 1mb with some value like null

If the debugging flag is off, I would just make invoker create and store the reason message and then the first 1MB of raw (no JSON) data string 

Something like
{
message: "Action result of X MB exceeds system limit of Y MB"
payload:"{ a:1, b:"c", ...,  z:"hell" "
}
payload above will be 1mb worth of data and it will be truncated z was suppose to be hello :-)


basically invoker takes the payload text from the response of the action proxy checks against the limit for the exception and then takes the first 1mb and stores it straig without trying to parse into JSON and try to find what are the largest fields to nuke to come up with a small 1mb  JSON to store
Is the 1MB already a configuration setting in ansible that operator can in their production deployment?

Would make sense to optimized even more by making the action proxy for the runtimes check the the size of the result and check against limit?

 That would save action proxy from 
Parsing the large data into json
Sending a large payload over network to invoker

Action will convert the response into an error response with a payload of the first 1mb raw data

Still invoker would need to implement the check for docker actions which are black box, but the runtimes pre installed we would trust.

Addressed feedback from @markusthoemmes. Thank you!

I'm guessing that the list of content types is finite and can be found here:
https://github.com/spray/spray/blob/master/spray-http/src/main/scala/spray/http/MediaType.scala#L282

But for users. I think it would be convenient to spell it out some where, when we doc this later.

In terms of binary data, I think decoding in the controller will be a bit of extra work to service an action invoke compare on the load that does today, but it should not be that big of a deal if the 1MB result limit is in place.

Which we should spell out for users, that they should not send large videos/pngs :-).

Should I assume from this code that the 1MB is for the whole result and also after the user does the base64 encoding?

Meaning that the user needs to be aware that sum of the headers, code, and the body after being encoded (base64) can't be larger than 1MB.

I don't have any other comments than as always excellent job on adding this feature, I want to support form-url-encoded to be able to implement a Slack command, and closing the circle on doing an entire web page including images.

@rabbah, please review.

@mdeuser I agree with your proposal on using `--full` this will match what we have today with `wsk activation list --full`
Which prints more details about each row/entry.

In addition I will request that we print two additional fields when using `--full` basepath and path

```
$ wsk -i api-experimental list --full
ok: APIs
Action: /whisk.system/mylongpkgname/mylongactionname
  Verb:       DELETE
  Name:       And the API Name is also quite long
  Base Path:  /my-basepath/is/quite/long
  Path:       /and/so/is/my/path
  URL:        http://172.17.0.1:9001/api/15c54aa3-6a07-4a78-9c4e-a70f73e73b93/my/basepath/is/quite/long/and/so/is/my/path
```

Below is the error I see when using the query parameter you posted. You must escape the new line as required by the JSON specification. For more information see: http://www.json.org/.

`
error: Unable to parse action command arguments: Invalid parameter argument '[]string{"{\n\t\"query\": \"UFJFRklYIHhzZDogPGh0dHA6Ly93d3cudzMub3JnLzIwMDEvWE1MU2NoZW1hIz4KUFJFRklYIGRj\\nOiA8aHR0cDovL3B1cmwub3JnL2RjL2VsZW1lbnRzLzEuMS8+ClBSRUZJWCA6IDwuPgoKU0VMRUNU\\nICoKeyA/cyA/cCA/byB9\\\"\n}\n"}': invalid character '\n' in string literal
`
PG approved.

Hello guys,
I am having a problem after generating an executable and pushing it to openwhisk.

1- I made and executable out of my python app, I tested it locally and then tried to create an openwhisk action from it using the steps in the blog post. When I tried to invoke it, I got the message `[Errno 2] No such file or directory`
2- I tried to create a docker image, I used `dockerskeleton` as the base image, I copied my `exec` to `action/exec`, I built the image and pushed it, then why I invoked the openwhisk action created from my image, I also received the same error `[Errno 2] No such file or directory`.

I browsed the docker image files, and I found the `exec` file in the `action` directory.
Do you have an idea what could be the problem?
If you can exec into the container, did you run the `/action/exec` directly to confirm it works?
Someone bumped into this issue and when I was asked for help, I was confused by the error as well. The example was a top-level `const`.

shouldn't we be doing the module wrappering at creation time? why wrapper it on every invocation?

we already support zip actions, and these impose an "action-as-module" requirement. so, to start with, the `wsk` CLI could turn any single-file javascript actions into zip actions, and upload the zip. that might solve most of the use cases, without having to mess with the invoker or any back-end bits.

(another point against eval: it obfuscates stack traces)
PG3 225 approved

Thanks Dominic for this pull request!

The git flow we follow is described here https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/wiki/Contributing:-Git-guidelines; as you said we can deal with that later. For reference PG refers to our Jenkins CI. For documentation it is not necessary usually. Lastly on protocol, have you submitted an Apache CLA?

This would close https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1431?

@sidfl15 are you suggesting this as an alternative way to drain action logs from their containers? 

FYI @perryibm

Yeah, Using the docker's log driver, it would be easier for draining logs to centralized logging service in a distributed environment. (In case of fluentd driver--> drain it to fluentd deamon running on a separate host)
For example, people using openwhisk with swift or other frameworks to make serverless applications would like to collect all the logs using fluentd or something.
While running a action, if we can specify which log driver to use as an option would be great.

Thank you for sharing, Rodric.
I will look into it

Yes I have submitted an Apache CLA, got the response and this would close #1431.
You may be interested in this as an example of how to drain your activation logs to an external sink: http://jamesthom.as/blog/2016/10/31/serverless-logs-with-elasticsearch/.
I'll give this a try - we don't have a CI for docker on mac but perhaps we should use this opportunity to set it up; @csantanapr what do you think?

Thanks for the blog, using logstash is one way, but for using different log drivers from docker would give flexibility for all kinds of users.
Moreover, with the option i am suggesting, there is no need to poll etc.
It would be great if you can add the functionality.
